543,544(TC) 2 bp del (Table 1, Frameshift and stop 543,544(TC) 2 bp del; PSV column indicates preserved speech variant)

One patient with preserved speech had a novel two-nucleotide deletion mutation at 543, 544 TC of MECP2, leading to the replacement of amino acids at 183-233 codons and causing a premature termination at 233 codon in 486 amino acids of the normal MECP2 product. author: Bartholdi D, et al.

cases.description: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification resulted in decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exons 1 and 2, suggesting the deletion of these exons. She did not learn to sit unaided ... She achieved only borderline hand use ... and did not produce any words.
cases.cohort_name: north-eastern Switzerland RTT cohort
cases.family_history: Unaffected parents; alteration not detected in either parent
cases.notes: X-inactivation: clear skewing (93%:7%) with preferential activation of the maternal allele.
quotes: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification resulted in decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exons 1 and 2, suggesting the deletion of these exons (Fig. 1).
The alteration was not detected in the DNAs of the unaffected parents.
Twenty girls with a clinical diagnosis of RTT were selected for this study.
For all four patients in whom we identified a mutation, severity was scored using the guidelines for reporting clinical features in cases with MECP2 mutations (17) (Table 2).
Scoring revealed 33 out of 40 points (Table 2), reflecting the severe phenotype of this girl.
She did not learn to sit unaided and started to shuffle with 12 months. She achieved only borderline hand use (incomplete palmar grasp, no pincer grasp) and did not produce any words.
The first generalized epileptic seizures occurred at the age of 4 years.

title: MECP2 Mutation in a Boy with Severe Neonatal Encephalopathy: Clinical, Neuropathological and Molecular Findings
author: Geerdink N, et al.

cases.description: The family history included a sister who was mentally retarded with autistic features. She was diagnosed as having RS when her brother was 8 months old. MECP2 mutation analysis with direct sequencing revealed a 488-489del in the patient's sister with RS (Fig. 3c). This mutation induced a frameshift and led to a truncated protein after ten amino acids.
cases.family_history: Brother (index case) had severe neonatal encephalopathy and carried the same MECP2 mutation hemizygously; mother negative in blood and likely germline mosaic; another sister healthy.
cases.notes: Sister is heterozygous carrier of the MECP2 488-489del; diagnosed with Rett syndrome with autistic features. Exact age and assessments not provided. File reference: Main text: Clinical findings; Molecular analysis; Fig. 3 caption.
quotes: The family history included a sister who was mentally retarded with autistic features.
She was diagnosed as having RS when her brother was 8 months old.
MECP2 mutation analysis with direct sequencing revealed a 488-489del in the patient’s sister with RS (Fig. 3c).
This mutation induced a frameshift and led to a truncated protein after ten amino acids, and was therefore almost certainly pathologic.
The same mutation was found heterozygously in the affected sister (panel c).
The mutation could not be identified in DNA isolated from blood of the mother, who is likely to carry the mutation in her germ-line.

title: Case Report: De novo DDX3X mutation caused intellectual disability in a female with skewed X-chromosome inactivation on the mutant allele
author: Sun Y, et al.

cases.description: The proband was a 10-year-old girl without family history. The symptoms of the proband included mild to moderate intellectual disability, delayed psychomotor development, poor speech development, infantile hypotonia, autism, and behavior problems. At the age of 7 years, she was diagnosed as autism spectrum disorder, the scores of childhood autism rating scale and autistic behavior checklist were 32 and 75.
cases.family_history: without family history
cases.notes: Extreme skewed X-chromosome inactivation with mutant allele on maternal X predominantly inactive; RNA allelic expression in PBMCs wild:mut ~71:29. ASD assessment scores: CARS=32; ABC=75.
quotes: “The proband was a 10-year-old girl without family history.” (Patient)

“The symptoms of the proband included mild to moderate intellectual disability, delayed psychomotor development, poor speech development, infantile hypotonia, autism, and behavior problems.” (Patient)
“At the age of 7 years, she was diagnosed as autism spectrum disorder, the scores of childhood autism rating scale and autistic behavior checklist were 32 and 75.” (Patient)
“Trio-based exome sequencing revealed a de novo heterozygous variant of NM_001193416.3: c.694_711dup18 (NC_000023.10: g.41203004_41203021dup18) in DDX3X gene of the female proband.” (Result)
“It indicated that the variant of NM_001193416.3: c.694_711dup18 occurred on the maternal X chromosome.” (Result)
“II.1 exhibited extreme skewing of XCI. The inactivated X-chromosome was linked with the 289 bp peak of AR, which inherited from the mother I.2.” (Figure 1C legend)
“The read counts for the DDX3X wild and mutant alleles were 586 and 244 (71:29), respectively, indicating that the mutant allele had lower expression (Figure 1D).” (Lower expression section)

phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Could not sit without support at 18 months; began to walk at 2 years; language level at 26 months equivalent to 12.7 months (Sym score: 5).
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Infantile hypotonia; mild to moderate intellectual disability.

variant.impact: In-frame duplication of six amino acids in a conserved region; classified as likely pathogenic (ACMG 1PS + 2PM).

title: A novel hypomorphic MECP2 point mutation is associated with a neuropsychiatric phenotype
author: Adegbola AA, et al.

cases.description: The proband, a 10-year old nondysmorphic female, presented with primarily neuropsychiatric manifestations and obesity with relative sparing of intelligence, language, growth, and gross motor skills. She was diagnosed with pervasive developmental disorder-not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS) at age 7 because of her insistence on sameness, preference for rituals, chronic inflexibility, inability to sustain conversations, and poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues. MECP2 sequencing identified a heterozygous c.454C>G (p.P152A) variant in exon 4, located in the methyl-binding domain; the same variant was present in her father.
cases.family_history: Father (46,XY) carries the same MECP2 c.454C>G (p.P152A) variant and has a history of behavioral dyscontrol, hyperactivity, anxiety, socialization and cognitive difficulties, and a learning disability; paternal grandmother reportedly has short stature, obesity, and cognitive problems (not genetically tested).
cases.notes: X-inactivation in proband was random (57:43). EEG abnormal with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges but no seizures. BMI 35.7. Head circumference tracked at ~98th percentile; described as macrocephalic with mild kyphosis in discussion.
quotes: The proband, a 10-year old nondysmorphic female, is the only child of her parents.

She was diagnosed with pervasive developmental disorder-not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS) at age 7 because of her insistence on sameness, preference for rituals, chronic inflexibility, inability to sustain conversations, and poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues.
Her electroencephalogram (EEG) is abnormal with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges, but no visualized seizure activity.

MECP2 gene sequencing (coding regions and flanking splice sites) revealed a single heterozygous nucleotide variant, c.454C>G in exon 4 (Genbank Accession Number NM_004992.2), resulting in the change of a proline to an alanine residue, p.P152A.
The same sequence variant was present in the father, who had a 46,XY karyotype in peripheral blood.
We identified and characterized a novel missense mutation (c.454C>G; p.P152A) in the critical methyl-binding domain of MeCP2 that disrupts MeCP2 functional activity.
The p.P152A mutation showed an approximate 40% decrease in its association with insoluble heterochromatin compared to wild-type.
WISC-IV revealed a full-scale intelligence quotient (FSIQ) in the mild ID range (Table 1).
The proband was administered the Bruininks-Oseretsky test of motor proficiency (BOT-2) ... which revealed a fine motor composite score of 20 (less than the first percentile).
8 years and 7 months revealed a Koppitz developmental score of 10 (fifth percentile), consistent with perceptual-motor difficulties.
Presence of autistic behavior: Mild; diagnosis of PDD-NOS.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Insistence on sameness; preference for rituals; chronic inflexibility; inability to sustain conversations; poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues; occasional hand-wringing stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: WISC-IV at 6y11m: FSIQ 70 (2nd %ile), Verbal 83 (13th), Perceptual Reasoning 69 (2nd), Working Memory 91 (27th), Processing Speed 56 (0.2nd). WISC-IV at 8y: FSIQ 58 (0.3rd), Verbal 81 (10th), Perceptual Reasoning 57 (0.2nd), Working Memory 65 (1st), Processing Speed 59 (0.3rd). BOT-2 fine motor composite 20 (<1st %ile). Koppitz developmental score at 8y7m: 10 (5th %ile).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: It is possible that behavioral problems associated with the proband's diagnosis of PDD-NOS prevented valid IQ testing, though adaptive behaviors as reported by teachers and parents are consistent with mild ID.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal early development; slowing of motor skills and hypotonia began at 12 months without documented regression; purposeful hand movements with occasional hand-wringing stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Mild intellectual disability; morbid obesity (BMI 35.7); abnormal EEG with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges (no seizures observed); genu valgum (knock-knees); pes planus (flat feet); macrocephaly (~98th percentile head circumference); mild kyphosis; frequent episodic aggressive outbursts; hypotonia; fine motor dysfunction; perceptual-motor difficulties.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Nondysmorphic; macrocephaly; mild kyphosis; genu valgum; pes planus; hypotonia; fine motor impairment; abnormal EEG without seizures; obesity; behavioral dyscontrol and aggressive outbursts.

title: First report of an unusual novel double mutation affecting the transcription repression domain of MeCP2 and causing a severe phenotype of Rett syndrome: Molecular analyses and computational investigation
author: Ghorbel R, et al.

cases.description: "The proband was native of northern Tunisia and was 4 years old girl, born from a non consanguineous marriage." "The patient showed clinical features fulfilling the main revised diagnostic criteria for typical Rett syndrome. Indeed, she showed a severe intellectual disability, an infantile encephalopathy with an autistic behavior." "The results revealed the presence of a novel de novo double-mutation in the exon 4 of the MECP2 gene: a new mutation c.695G > T (p.G232V) and the common c.880 C > T transition (p.R294X) (Fig. 1A)."
cases.cohort_name: Department of Child and Adolescent Neurology, National Institute Mongi Ben Hmida of Neurology, Tunis, Tunisia
cases.family_history: Non-consanguineous parents; one healthy sister; parents unaffected.
cases.notes: Two heterozygous de novo variants reported in exon 4 affecting the TRD domain; phase (cis/trans) not stated. Sources: Section 2.1 Patient; Section 3.1 Mutational analyses.
quotes: The proband was native of northern Tunisia and was 4 years old girl, born from a non consanguineous marriage.
The patient showed clinical features fulfilling the main revised diagnostic criteria for typical Rett syndrome.
Indeed, she showed a severe intellectual disability, an infantile encephalopathy with an autistic behavior.
In addition, this patient developed epilepsy in the age of 12 months. Besides, motor development delay and sleep disorder were detected in the studied patient.
Onset of stereotypic hand movements, severe cognitive impairment with absence of language, progressive scoliosis and autistic features were revealed.
The extensive sequencing of the four exons of the MECP2 gene and their flanking exon-intron boundaries was performed in the Tunisian patient with Rett syndrome and her family members.
The results revealed the presence of a novel de novo double-mutation in the exon 4 of the MECP2 gene: a new mutation c.695G > T (p.G232V) and the common c.880 C > T transition (p.R294X) (Fig. 1A).
In fact, the novel transition c.695G > T was present in the studied patient at heterozygous state... Besides it is a de novo mutation since it was absent in the patient's parents.
In addition, the common c.880 C > T transition was present at heterozygous state in the studied patient and was absent in her unaffected parents and sister.

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Severe intellectual disability; infantile encephalopathy; epilepsy (onset at 12 months); sleep disorder; progressive scoliosis.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Typical Rett syndrome with stereotypic hand movements; progressive scoliosis.

variant.sequencing_method_details: Sequencing of all four MECP2 exons and flanking exon-intron boundaries in proband and family members (Sanger); parental and sibling testing performed.
variant.variant_description: Novel de novo double-mutation in MECP2 exon 4: missense c.695G>T (p.G232V) and nonsense c.880C>T (p.R294X), both heterozygous and absent in parents and sister.
variant.impact: p.R294X predicts truncation (loss-of-function); p.G232V predicted deleterious; both in TRD domain.
variant.segregation_data: Both variants heterozygous in proband; absent in parents and sister (de novo).

title: Novel de novo Nonsense Mutation of MECP2 in a Patient with Rett Syndrome
author: Kim S, et al.

cases.description: "She was found to have a novel heterozygous nonsense mutation, 129C>T (Q19X), which leads to the most severely truncated MECP2 protein reported to date. Sequencing of parental DNA revealed the mutation was de novo. The patient was not affected with microcephaly or hyperventilation, but had other features of Rett syndrome including severe mental retardation and symptoms of autistic disorder."
cases.cohort_name: autism clinic (suspected RTT referral)
cases.notes: Moderately skewed X-chromosome inactivation (1.74:1) reported. No microcephaly; normal respiratory pattern. Fragile X ruled out; Angelman syndrome suspected but 15q11-q13 deletion not found and UPD not assessed.
quotes: [Abstract] "She was found to have a novel heterozygous nonsense mutation, 129C>T (Q19X), which leads to the most severely truncated MECP2 protein reported to date. Sequencing of parental DNA revealed the mutation was de novo. The patient was not affected with microcephaly or hyperventilation, but had other features of Rett syndrome including severe mental retardation and symptoms of autistic disorder."
[Patient] "The patient was a five-year-old girl at the time of evaluation."
[Patient] "She had had a regression in purposeful hand movements, lost speech consisting of a few single words, lost eye gaze and lost social smiling in the latter her second year."
[Patient] "Complex partial seizures were identified at 22 months and treated with carbamazepine."
[Patient] "She had continuous patting and clasping movements of her hands."
[Patient] "She did not have microcephaly (head circumference 47.25 cm at 24 months and 51 cm at 59 months). She had a normal respiratory pattern."
[Patient] "a consulting pediatric neurologist diagnosed RTT one month before our evaluation"
[Results and Discussion] "The patient was found to have a heterozygous nonsense mutation of MECP2 : 129C>T leading to Q19X (Fig. 1)."
[Results and Discussion] "Neither of the parents' DNA showed a mutation, demonstrating this is a de novo mutation."
[Results and Discussion] "A moderately skewed XCI pattern (1.74:1) may have contributed to the absence of microcephaly and hyperventilation."
[Figure 1 legend] "Y indicates C/T transition at nucleotide position 129 in X99686."

title: Three intellectual disability-associated de novo mutations in MECP2 identified by trioWES analysis
author: Gu Y, et al.

cases.description: The 8-year-old girl (case 2) carries the p.(Arg306Cys) mutation. At 3 years and 1 month, she was found to avoid eye-contact and interaction with others. Clancy Behavior Scale measurement suggested possible autism. Although this patient had hand stereotypy, her normal head growth did not support the diagnosis of RTT. Considering her overall developmental delay and autistic-like features after 6 months, the diagnosis of Xlinked ID, psychomotor retardation and possible Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) was made.
cases.notes: Sanger sequencing confirmed de novo status; EEG showed multifocal epileptic-like discharges without clinical seizures; brain MRI and AEP were normal.
quotes: The 8-year-old girl (case 2, Fig. 2b), who carries the p.(Arg306Cys) mutation, was healthy at birth.
At 3 years and 1 month, she was found to avoid eye-contact and interaction with others.
Clancy Behavior Scale measurement suggested possible autism.
At 7 years and 4 months, she showed stereotypic hand movements; her height was 117 cm (15-50th), body weight was 24 kg (50th). Brain MRI and AEP were normal.

Although this patient had hand stereotypy, her normal head growth did not support the diagnosis of RTT [10]. Considering her overall developmental delay and autistic-like features after 6 months, the diagnosis of Xlinked ID, psychomotor retardation and possible Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) was made [18].

A nonsense [NC_000023.10: g.153296777G > A, NM_ 004992.3: c.502C > T, p.(Arg168*)] and two missense mutations [NC_000023.10: g.153296363G > A, NM_ 004992.3: c.916C > T, p.(Arg306Cys); NC_000023.10: g.153296400G > C, NM_004992.3: c.879C > G, p.(Ile293Met)] in exon 4 of MECP2 were identified in case 1, case 2 and case 3 respectively.
All of the mutations were de novo heterozygous in the affected individuals.
Fig. 2 Sanger sequencing of the mutation c.916C > T, p.(Arg360Cys) of MECP2 in case 2. a The mutation is present in the proband, but not in the parents, is confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
Although she did not have a seizure history, EEG detected multifocal epileptic-like discharges during her sleep.

title: Transcriptome and Genome Analysis Uncovers a DMD Structural Variant
author: Folland C, et al.

cases.description: The proband had a typical DMD clinical presentation, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and dystrophinopathy on muscle biopsy.
cases.family_history: There was no relevant family history.
cases.notes: Single proband case report with DMD paracentric inversion and a DIP2B 5' UTR CGG repeat expansion. Authors note uncertainty regarding the clinical significance of the DIP2B expansion; blood methylation of the expanded allele was not increased. Results section states IQ and language within normal limits despite abstract/intro mention of mild intellectual disability. File reference: Main text: Abstract; Results; Discussion; Figure 3B.
quotes: Results: "The proband had a typical DMD clinical presentation with delayed motor development; he first walked at 18 -20 months of age... He had ASD with poor socialization at school, no friends, and engaged in solo play. His IQ and language were within normal limits."
Results: "There was no relevant family history."
Results: "Skeletal muscle immunoperoxidase staining revealed a complete absence of dystrophin (Figure 1, A and B), consistent with dystrophinopathy."
Results: "Genomic SRS identified a 216 kb paracentric inversion (NC_000023.11:g.33162217-33378800) overlapping 2 DMD promoters."
Results: "ExpansionHunter indicated an expansion of 109 CGG repeats within the 5′ UTR of DIP2B."

Results/Figure 3B: "Targeted LRS confirmed the presence of the large inversion spanning the promoters of Dp427c and Dp427m and the repeat expansion in DIP2B... A heterozygous expansion (270 × CGG) was detected in the patient but absent in healthy controls (n = 10)."
Discussion: "DMD can be associated with cognitive involvement, including autism spectrum disorders."
Discussion: "There was no evidence of hypermethylation on the expanded haplotype, which was predominantly unmethylated at the DIP2B promoter in whole blood."

STR analysis suggested DIP2B 5′ UTR CGG expansion (~109 CGG by ExpansionHunter), confirmed and sized by targeted nanopore long-read sequencing at ~270 × CGG; expansion was heterozygous and lacked promoter hypermethylation in blood.

quotes: “The boy was reported to develop normally until the age of 18 mo when he began to display some autistic features such as monotonous playing, stereotyped and clumsy hand movements, and social withdrawal. Regression of acquired skills such as speech development became gradually apparent.” (Patients and Methods: Patient 1)
“He was hyperactive and presented disruptive behavior and attention-deficit disorder.” (Patients and Methods: Patient 1)

“DNA sequencing in patient 1 revealed a substitution of a cytosine by thymidine at position 316 in exon 3, predicted to result in an arginine to tryptophane amino acid change in the MBD at the position 106 of the MeCP2 protein (R106W) … the sequencing chromatogram showed two nucleotide peaks at the variant base position, suggesting the existence of two cell lines and thus a possible somatic mosaicism.” (Results)
“the mother was also tested, revealing a normal sequence.” (Results)
“An extra X chromosome was excluded by chromosomal analysis, but the results of sequencing analysis of leukocyte DNA strongly supported the evidence of somatic mosaicism.” (Discussion)
“Patient 1 exhibited the R106W (c.916 C > T) missense mutation, among the eight most common mutations in the MECP2 gene …” (Discussion)

title: SHANK1 Deletions in Males with Autism Spectrum Disorder
author: Sato D, et al.

cases.description: III-5 (male) ASD e : Asperger disorder (ADI-R and ADOS-4) and anxiety
cases.cohort_name: Family 1 (Canadian ASD cohort)
cases.family_history: Multigenerational family with SHANK1 deletion; also present in males I-1, IV-1, IV-3 and females II-4, III-2.
cases.notes: Deletion validated by breakpoint sequencing; co-segregating PCDHGA11 Tyr313* nonsense variant on 5q31.3 reported in family 1. Sources: Main text (Results); Table 1; Figure 1; Figure 2.
quotes: We initially identified a hemizygous microdeletion in chromosomal region 19q13.33 in ASD proband III-5 from the Canadian cohort (see family 1 in Table 1 and Figure 1).
The deletion, which was determined to be 63.8 kb, eliminated exons 1-20 of SHANK1 and the neighboring CLEC11A (MIM 604713)
The accurate coordinates for family 1 were mapped by sequencing across the breakpoints and are Chr 19: 55,872,189-55,935,995 (hg18).
Subsequent genotyping in family 1 revealed that the deletion was also present in males I-1, IV-1, and IV-3 as well as in females II-4 and III-2 (Figure 1).
III-5 (male) ASD e : Asperger disorder (ADI-R and ADOS-4) and anxiety
Leiter-R: brief NVIQ = 83 (13th %ile; LA)
OWLS: TL = 68 (2nd %ile; delay)
VABS-I: ABC = 52 (< 1st %ile), COM = 43 (< 1st %ile), DLS = 63 (1st %ile), and SOC = 65 (1st %ile); he currently takes olanzapine and paroxetine for the anxiety disorder

When III-5 was 25 years old, the ADI-R and ADOS diagnosed him with autism according to the cut-offs, but his current best-estimate diagnoses are that of Asperger disorder ... and a separate anxiety disorder; ... now, at age 32, he lives independently and works in a sheltered workshop.

title: Two affected boys in a Rett syndrome family
author: Villard L, et al.

cases.description: Patient III-3 is a 17-year-old girl with typical Rett syndrome. She fulfilled eight of the nine international criteria: normal pregnancy and birth, normal early development, normal head circumference at birth, later slowing of head growth, loss of purposeful hand skills between ages 6 and 30 months associated with deterioration in communication and social withdrawal, development of severely impaired expressive and receptive language and presence of apparent severe psychomotor retardation, stereotypic hand movements, and diagnosis tentative until age 2 to 5 years.
cases.family_history: Two brothers (III-2 and III-4) died in infancy from severe encephalopathy; mother (II-2) is a carrier of the T158M mutation with completely skewed X-chromosome inactivation; mutation absent in other tested relatives (I-1, I-2, II-1, III-1).
cases.notes: Missing Rett criterion: absence of gait apraxia and truncal apraxia/ataxia between ages 1 and 4 years. No epilepsy or vasomotor disturbances of the lower limbs reported.
quotes: “Patient III-3 is a 17-year-old girl with typical Rett syndrome.” (Results – Clinical findings)

“She fulfilled eight of the nine international criteria: normal pregnancy and birth, normal early development, normal head circumference at birth, later slowing of head growth, loss of purposeful hand skills between ages 6 and 30 months associated with deterioration in communication and social withdrawal, development of severely impaired expressive and receptive language and presence of apparent severe psychomotor retardation, stereotypic hand movements, and diagnosis tentative until age 2 to 5 years.” (Results – Clinical findings)

“Sequencing revealed the presence of a mutation (C to T nucleotide change resulting in the T158M amino acid change) both in the mother's and in her affected daughter's DNA.” (Results – Identification of a mutation in MECP2)
“Abnormal restriction fragments (arrows) indicate that individuals II-2 and III-3 are carriers of the mutation.” (Figure 2A legend)
“The mother of the patients is a carrier of the T158M mutation.” (Abstract)
“mutation was not found in the DNA of the other members of the family (I-1, I-2, II-1, and III-1).” (Results – Identification of a mutation in MECP2)

“Rett patients stop developing at about 1 year old, and have a series of clinical signs indicative of a neurodegenerative process: arrest of brain development, regression of acquisitions, and behavioral troubles (stereotypic hand movement, autism).” (Introduction)

title: Autistic-like Behaviors Associated with a Novel Non-Canonical Splice-Site DDX3X Variant: A Case Report of a Rare Clinical Syndrome
author: Stefaniak U, et al.

cases.description: We report a 7 year old nonverbal female with a likely novel de novo pathogenic heterozygous variant in the DDX3X gene affecting the non-canonical splice-site in the intron 1 (NM_001356:c.45+12G>A). (Abstract)
cases.family_history: No genetic conditions in the family; no children with IDD beyond the second generation; no epilepsy.
cases.notes: Paternal DNA not available. DDX3X variant classified as VUS at time of testing; in-silico suggests splicing impact. Additional HSD17B4 VUS were in cis and maternally inherited; Perrault syndrome ruled out. First reported Polish individual with DDX3X-associated disorder in this paper.
quotes: We report a 7 year old nonverbal female with a likely novel de novo pathogenic heterozygous variant in the DDX3X gene affecting the non-canonical splice-site in the intron 1 (NM_001356:c.45+12G>A). (Abstract)
The patient initially received a diagnosis of ASD as the result of a psychological test at three years of age, (Discussion)
a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) (Abstract)

In an evaluation at three years of age revealed behaviors related to ASD, such as stereotypy, problems with imitation movements that suggested problems with mirror neurons, and dysfunction with sensory processing: tactile defensiveness, lack of speech, and occasional sleep disturbances. (Materials and Methods)
GENE DDX3X ... TRANSCRIPT NM_001356.4 ... NOMENCLATURE c.45+12G>A ... CONSEQUENCE intron_variant ... GENOTYPE HET ... CLASSIFICATION Variant of uncertain significance (Table 2)

the variant in DDX3X previously not reported in population databases [13] was found to be absent in the maternal sample and hence likely a de novo event. Even though the paternal sample was not available for co-segregation studies, (Materials and Methods following Table 2)
At the age of four, she was diagnosed with celiac disease, which confirmed the cause of her severe constipation in earlier years. (Materials and Methods)

The patient's brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging MRI examination did not reveal any abnormalities ... an arachnoid cyst shaping the front surface of the temporal lobe had been found on the right side ... a slight delayed myelination of white matter (Materials and Methods/Figures 1–4)

As can be seen in Table 3, the patient in this study scored v-scale scores for the following skills: 1 for receptive (low), 2 for expressive (low), 4 for written (low), 9 for personal (low), 6 for domestic (low), 6 for community (low), 6 for interpersonal (low), 6 for play and leisure (low), 5 for coping (low), 13 for gross motor (moderately low), and 8 for fine motor skills (low). (Results/Table 3)
This is the first study to report a case of a Polish individual with a DDX3X -associated disorder. (Discussion)

The patient, who is currently 7 years old, was the first-born child. ... there were no genetic conditions in this family, children with IDD beyond the second generation, or a diagnosis of epilepsy. (Materials and Methods)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Nonverbal/lack of speech; stereotypy; limited and repetitive patterns of behavior; problems with imitation movements; social difficulties/unresponsive to environmental cues; sleep disturbance; sensory processing dysfunction (tactile defensiveness).

phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Nonverbal; stereotypies; sensory processing dysfunction (tactile defensiveness); sleep disturbance; high pain threshold; temperature dysregulation; right temporal arachnoid cyst; delayed myelination; spinal asymmetry.

Additional HSD17B4 missense variants (c.11C>G p.Pro4Arg; c.482A>G p.Glu161Gly) were benign/tolerated in silico and in cis from mother.

title: Biophysical classification of a CACNA1D de novo mutation as a high-risk mutation for a severe neurodevelopmental disorder
author: Hofer NT, et al.

cases.description: The CACNA1D variant (chr3: 53757881 C>T, human reference genome hg19) was predicted to cause a p.Ser652Leu (S652L) mutation (reference sequence NM_001128839). The patients (DECIPHER database individuals #262954 and #262956; decipher.sanger.ac.uk) are male monozygotic twins, thirteen years old at present, and both harbor one copy of the mutation. Their clinical phenotype has been updated recently. It manifests as a severe neurodevelopmental phenotype with delayed speech and language development and a global developmental delay. Both individuals show self-injurious behaviors and have been diagnosed with ASD two years ago.

cases.family_history: Monozygotic twins; described as de novo in the proband; parents unaffected.
cases.notes: Both twins also carried a KIF22 frameshift (c.1934_1935insG (p.Glu646GlyfsTer), chr16: 29816479 T>TG, hg19), which the authors argue is unlikely to explain the neurodevelopmental phenotype. Additional features (tall stature, undescended testes, seizures at age 2 without recurrence, ADHD-like symptoms, facial dysmorphism) were reported for only one twin; the paper does not specify which DECIPHER ID. Source location: Results section.

[Results] "The patients (DECIPHER database individuals #262954 and #262956; decipher.sanger.ac.uk) are male monozygotic twins, thirteen years old at present, and both harbor one copy of the mutation."

[Results] "It manifests as a severe neurodevelopmental phenotype with delayed speech and language development and a global developmental delay. Both individuals show self-injurious behaviors and have been diagnosed with ASD two years ago."

[Results] "A frameshift mutation (c.1934_1935insG (p.Glu646GlyfsTer)) in the KIF22 gene (chr16: 29816479 T>TG, human reference genome hg19) was also identified in both patients... Therefore, the KIF22 mutation is unlikely to explain the severe neurodevelopmental phenotype of the two patients."

title: Case Report: Lennox -Gastaut Epileptic Encephalopathy Responsive to Cannabidiol Treatment Associated With a Novel de novo Mosaic SHANK1 Variant
author: Paprocka J, et al.

cases.description: An 11-year-old boy with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, global developmental delay, and autistic features without congenital defects or facial dysmorphic features and negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders was referred for WES. On psychological evaluation, moderate intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder were found.
cases.family_history: negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders
cases.notes: Lennox-Gastaut epileptic encephalopathy with polymorphic seizures beginning at age 2; refractory epilepsy markedly responsive to cannabidiol with >4 years seizure freedom; generalized hypotonia; normal MRI and metabolic workup; head circumference 52 cm (10th centile).
quotes: An 11-year-old boy with Lennox -Gastaut syndrome, global developmental delay, and autistic features without congenital defects or facial dysmorphic features and negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders was referred for WES.
On psychological evaluation, moderate intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder were found.

A heterozygous variant in the SHANK1 gene [hg38; chr19: g.050716358-C > G, NM\_016148.5: c.376 /equals /G > C, p.(Gly126Arg)] ( Figure 2 ) was found on 21% of all reads (N /equals 113/X), suggesting it was mosaic.
Co-segregation studies using ADS con /uniFB01 rmed the variant as de novo and showed mosaicism at the level of 19% of reads (N /equals 7995).
The analysis of the WES data and variant prioritization were performed, as previously described (Ploski et al., 2014), except that the Hg38 human genome version was used for alignment.
The first epileptic seizures appeared at the age of 2 years.
Polymorphic seizures (tonic -clonic, atonic, myoclonic, and absence seizures) required numerous changes of therapy.
After cannabidiol administration, the epileptic seizures stopped, and the patient has been seizure-free for > 4 years now.
The most recent neurological examination showed the head circumference of 52 cm (10th centile) and generalized hypotonia with preserved tendon re /uniFB02 exes.

The SHANK1 heterozygous p.Gly126Arg variant found in our patient is a previously unreported missense mutation which occurred de novo , most likely as an early postzygotic event present in approximately 40% of mature cells.

phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Moderate intellectual disability.

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome; refractory epilepsy (seizure freedom on cannabidiol); generalized hypotonia; status epilepticus (twice, responsive to IV benzodiazepines); head circumference 52 cm (10th centile); EEG: generalized paroxysmal changes with slow spike-and-wave complexes (<3 Hz)

variant.variant_description: Heterozygous mosaic missense variant detected at 21% of reads by WES; confirmed de novo and mosaic at 19% by ADS; located in a highly conserved region of the SHANK1 N-terminal domain.
variant.impact: Absent from population databases; in silico analyses indicate deleterious effect on protein structure and interactions.
variant.segregation_data: De novo by ADS; mosaic in blood (~21% WES; 19% ADS); parents tested negative.

title: Rett syndrome from quintuple and triple deletions within the MECP 2 deletion hotspot region
author: Lebo RV, et al.

cases.description: A 6-year-old Taiwanese female, product of IVF, with early development including two words by age 1 and walking at 15 months. Later showed autistic behavior, impaired balance, hypertonicity, breathing difficulties including hyperventilation, and abnormal EEG consistent with a seizure disorder. At age 6 she exhibited typical autistic behavior, hand-wringing movements, developmental delay, dystonia, suspected atonic seizures at night, bruxism, hyperventilation, and head circumference at the 2nd percentile. Genetic testing identified a triple deletion in MECP2 exon 4 totaling −113 bp, causing a frameshift and premature termination (364 aa protein).
cases.family_history: Mother had breast cancer; conceived by IVF; high-resolution karyotypes of proband and parents normal.
cases.notes: PCR showed predominant amplification of the shorter deleted allele with minor normal-length product; both parents tested normal at the Rett locus, consistent with a de novo event.
quotes: Only limited information exists on this 6-year-old Taiwanese female...
When examined, her autistic behavior was noted, as was the lack of progress in language acquisition.
When seen again at the age of 6, she exhibited typical autistic behavior, hand-wringing movements, and was considerably delayed.
She was dystonic and thought to have atonic seizures at night, grinding of her teeth, and hyperventilating. Her head circumference was in the 2nd percentile.

The MECP 2 exon 4 gene regions of propositus 2 were again sequenced... The first unequal recombination site deleting 15 bp... the second... 28 bp... the third... 70 bp... Together, these three deletions result in an exon 4 that is 113 bp shorter...
Thus, the gene terminates 19 amino acids after the first deletion, resulting in a 364-amino acid translated protein instead of the normal 486-amino acid protein (Fig. 4B3).
a small quantity of normal length PCR amplified product could be observed in the same electrophoretic lane as the amplified abnormal allele (sample C1 in Fig. 2B).
Subsequently, testing available DNAs confirmed that two different X chromosomes are present in approximately equal quantities in each propositus (Table 4).
Rett: DeletionX3 ... Father of propositus 2: Normal ... Mother of propositus 2: Normal

title: Role of a conserved glutamine in the function of voltage-gated Ca 2 ÷ channels revealed by a mutation in human CACNA1D
author: Garza-Lopez E, et al.

cases.description: The male proband was the first-born child of healthy parents who were first cousins of Arabic descent. The father had a history of febrile seizures since childhood. The proband was born after an uneventful pregnancy and delivered at 38 weeks of gestation by cesarean section because of fetal distress. He failed the hearing test at birth and had seizures beginning at 4 months of age. At the age of 4 1 /2 years, he was reassessed at the genetic clinic for the purpose of family planning. He did not speak and his comprehension was limited. He exhibited autistic behaviors including very limited eye contact and hyperactivity. He wore hearing aids from the age of 11 months. At 5 years of age, he underwent hearing tests which revealed moderate hearing loss (40-50 db SPL across all frequencies from 500 Hz to 40 kHz). Whole-exome sequencing and filtering for homozygous variants revealed two potential candidate genes: A homozygous mutation in the otogelin gene (OTOG) ... and a homozygous missense variant in CACNA1D: Chr3 (GRCh37): g.53756476G > C; NM_000720.3: c.1701G > C (p.Gln567His). ... Both parents were heterozygous for the OTOG and CACNA1D variants. The high degree of consanguinity within the family was the basis for assuming a recessive model of inheritance. ... CACNA1D variants have also been associated with autism spectrum disorders (8) and epilepsy (8, 17, 18). Because of the coincident involvement of CACNA1D in the proband's symptoms (i.e. hearing loss, epilepsy, autism), we analyzed the functional consequences of the CACNA1D in a heterologous expression system.
cases.family_history: father had a history of febrile seizures since childhood; parents are first cousins
cases.notes: Also carries a homozygous OTOG c.4439C>T (p.Thr1480Ile) variant, likely relevant to hearing loss. Homozygous for CACNA1D variant due to consanguinity.
quotes: He failed the hearing test at birth and had seizures beginning at 4 months of age. At the age of 4 1/2 years, he was reassessed at the genetic clinic for the purpose of family planning. Whole-exome sequencing and filtering for homozygous variants revealed two potential candidate genes: ... a homozygous missense variant in CACNA1D: Chr3 (GRCh37): g.53756476G > C; NM_000720.3: c.1701G > C (p.Gln567His).
Both parents were heterozygous for the OTOG and CACNA1D variants.

CACNA1D variants have also been associated with autism spectrum disorders (8) and epilepsy (8, 17, 18). Results/Genetics: "The balanced pericentric inversion was detected in the proband, affected maternal half-brother, and mother (heterozygous carrier for the inversion)."
Figure 2 legend: "Highresolution karyotyping confirming the pericentric inversion in the mother (left chromosome) and the affected brother (arrows depict the breakpoints)."

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy/dystrophinopathy; developmental delay; sensorineural hearing loss; elevated creatine kinase

variant.sequencing_method: Clinical whole-genome sequencing (cWGS); high-resolution karyotyping confirmed inversion in this brother and mother
variant.region: Xp21.1 (DMD intron 55) and Xq21.1 (~443 kb upstream of POU3F4)
variant.variant_description: Novel 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X disrupting DMD and impacting upstream regulatory region of POU3F4.
variant.impact: Breakpoint in DMD intron 55 predicted to cause premature transcription termination and nonsense-mediated decay; breakpoint upstream of POU3F4 associated with hearing loss.
variant.segregation_data: Detected in affected maternal half-brother and proband; mother heterozygous carrier. Karyotype 46,Y,inv(X)(p21.1q21.1) confirmed in mother and affected brother.

title: Preserved speech variant is allelic of classic Rett syndrome
author: De Bona C, et al.

cases.description: Case109 has already been fully described as case report (case I-12) in Zappella et al . At present the patient is 13 years old, is in the third stage and her conditions have remained essentially the same as in the description given. She is an obese girl with a high kyphosis, has continuous stereotypic hand-washing activities, speaks in short phrases in the second and third person with echolalias, and has a mental age close to 3-4 years. She also has flat feet, genu valgum and a dyspraxic gait. She has a large head circumference (56.5 cm), albeit within 2 SD. A recent waking EEG shows a basic rhythm of 8 c/s with bursts of 6-7 c/s activities: she has never had epileptic seizures.
cases.cohort_name: preserved speech variant (PSV) of the Rett complex
cases.notes: Paper states that two PSV cases (case 32 and case 109) carry small frameshift deletions in MECP2 (one 41 bp and one 44 bp) causing truncation at p.404, but does not specify which exact deletion (1157del41 vs 1159del44) corresponds to case 109.
quotes: “Case109 has already been fully described as case report (case I-12) in Zappella et al . … At present the patient is 13 years old … She is an obese girl with a high kyphosis, has continuous stereotypic hand-washing activities, speaks in short phrases in the second and third person with echolalias … She has a large head circumference (56.5 cm) … she has never had epileptic seizures.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)
“Four very similar small deletions were found in two classic RTT patients and in two (out of three) preserved speech variants (case 32 and case 109, Figure 3).” (Results)

“The deletion of 41 bp (starting from nt1157) and the two deletions of 41bp and 44bp (starting from nt1159) led to the same frameshift and to protein truncation in position 404, after a short stretch of incorrect amino acids.” (Results)
“1157del41 … Phenotype: PSV” and “1159del44 … Phenotype: PSV” (Table 1)
“Their behaviour fulfils the characteristics of an autistic disorder.” (Discussion – referring to PSV)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Stereotypic hand-washing; echolalia; PSV explicitly linked to autistic disorder in discussion.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Mental age close to 3–4 years (at chronological age 13 years).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe intellectual disability inferred from mental age estimate; no gold-standard ASD diagnostic tools reported, which may reduce ASD phenotype confidence.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: High kyphosis; obesity; flat feet; genu valgum; dyspraxic gait; macrocephaly within 2 SD; no epileptic seizures.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Rett preserved speech variant (PSV); continuous stereotypic hand-washing; echolalic short phrases; dyspraxic gait; orthopedic issues (flat feet, genu valgum); macrocephaly within 2 SD; no seizures.

variant.region: 3′ coding region (downstream of the transcription repression domain)
variant.variant: c.1157del41 or c.1159del44 (exact assignment to this case not specified); frameshift with truncation at ~p.(…/404*)
variant.variant_description: Small out-of-frame deletion (41 bp or 44 bp) near nt1157/1159 in MECP2; creates frameshift and truncation at position 404.
variant.impact: Frameshift resulting in premature truncation at amino acid position 404.

In 2004, at the latest follow-up, at the age of 47 years, she was a very small woman, 134 cm tall, weighing 50 kg, with an OFC of 54 cm. (Case S-1)
She has a complex MECP2 rearrangement with deletions both of exon 3 and exon 4, as reported in detail by Erlandsson and Hagberg in this issue. (Case S-1)
To summarize, this 47-year-old woman fulfills the criteria for classic Rett syndrome stage III. (Case S-1)

title: Classic Rett syndrome in a boy with R133C mutation of MECP2
author: Masuyama T, et al.

cases.description: Boy with classic Rett syndrome carrying an MECP2 R133C missense mutation; hemizygous with maternal origin. Clinical course includes autistic tendencies, stereotypic hand movements, seizures, loss of mobility leading to being bed-ridden by 8 years.
cases.family_history: Mother heterozygous MECP2 R133C with very mild intellectual impairment; sister heterozygous R133C with classic RTT.
cases.notes: Normal 46,XY karyotype; no evidence of somatic mosaicism. MRI with mild frontal/temporal atrophy. Managed with noninvasive ventilation and tube feeding by age 10. File reference: Main text: Title, Abstract, Section 2 Case report, Section 4 Results; Figure 2(A).
quotes: Classic Rett syndrome in a boy with R133C mutation of MECP2
We report herein a boy with classic RTT in a family with a missense mutation in MECP2.
The R133C mutation was present in MECP2 without somatic mosaicism.
The C-to-T change at 397 in exon 4 of MECP2 that resulted in R133C was detected in three members of this family (Fig. 2(A)).

The mother and the sister were heterozygous for R133C (Fig. 2(A): M and S), and the boy had only one allele, C133, derived from the mother (Fig. 2(A): P). The father displayed a wild-type allele, Rl33 (Fig. 2(A): F).
At this time, strong interest was shown in sound-producing toys, with little interest towards people, indicating autistic tendencies.
At 5-years-old, stereotypic hand movements were observed (Fig. 1).
At about 4-years-old, the patient suffered generalized convulsions.
He became bed-ridden by 8-years-old.
Chromosome analysis revealed a 46, XY karyotype.

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Generalized convulsions; hypotonia; rigidity and dystonic hypertonicity; dystonic posture; thoracic scoliosis; feeding difficulties requiring gastric tube; irregular breathing during wakefulness.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Classic Rett syndrome phenotype with regression and stereotypic hand movements.

author: Curie A, et al.

cases.description: “Both patients fulfilled the Pervasive Developmental Disorder criteria on Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule and Asperger syndrome criteria on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed. (DSM-IV).” “We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile).” “Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58. A diagnosis of dyspraxia was made.” “At 9 years, he had delusional ideas with interpreting processes, and was hearing interior voices. Early-onset schizophrenia was therefore suspected.”

quotes: “Here, we report on two high-functioning brothers who have Asperger's syndrome and early-onset schizophrenia that are associated with a novel pathogenic MECP2 deleterious variant…” [Introduction/Abstract]

“Both patients fulfilled the Pervasive Developmental Disorder criteria on Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule and Asperger syndrome criteria on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed. (DSM-IV).” [Abstract]
“Both patients fulfilled the criteria for autistic spectrum disorder on ADOS (Table 1) and Asperger syndrome on DSM-IV.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“ADOS - generic module 3 (cutoff autistic spectrum disorder: 10) | 12 | …” [Table 1]
“Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58. A diagnosis of dyspraxia was made.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“At 9 years, he had delusional ideas with interpreting processes, and was hearing interior voices. Early-onset schizophrenia was therefore suspected.” [Patient 1]
“Psychiatric diagnosis (DSM-IV TR criteria) | Asperger syndrome, early-onset schizophrenia …” [Table 1]

“We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile) (Fig. 1).” [Genetic analysis]

“Electropherograms show that the two affected dizygotic twins (II2 and II3) carry the c.491 G > T; p.(Ser164Ile) transversion of MECP2, whereas only the normal allele is seen in the mother’s (I2) and sister’s blood DNA. This suggests a maternal germline mosaicism.” [Fig. 1 caption]
“The mutation was not observed in blood-extracted DNA from the mother, suggesting germline mosaicism.” [Genetic analysis]

“Age-related Wechsler Scale (WISC-III) was performed in both patients … Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“At 8 years and 6 months, he showed a central early-onset puberty.” [Patient 1]

“Ten days later, he showed major asthenia and extrapyramidal symptoms. Biological analysis indicated a major hyperammonemia (673 µmol/l) that decreased again to normal values after valproate withdrawal.” [Patient 1]

title: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Successfully Treated with Aripiprazole in a Patient with Autism Spectrum Disorder Symptoms Including Irritability
author: Noda S, et al.

cases.description: We experienced a case of DMD associated with severe psychotic symptoms in a 19-year-old Japanese male patient... At a later date, a genetic test ... revealed a frameshift variant (p. Leu 3376fs) of exon 70 in his DMD gene. With the revision of DSM-5 criteria, he was diagnosed to have ASD. In the WISC-IV test, his FSIQ was 49.
cases.family_history: He had no family history of neuromuscular disorders.
cases.notes: Diagnosed with DMD at 3 years via muscle biopsy; pervasive developmental disorder at 4 years, later ASD per DSM-5; WISC-IV at admission showed FSIQ 49 with low indices; developed severe psychotic symptoms at 17 years (irritability, insomnia, hallucinations, delusions); treated with aripiprazole 6 mg/day with good response; heart failure treated with carvedilol/captopril at 15; nocturnal respiratory failure requiring NIPPV at 16; MRI showed mild cerebral atrophy; lost ambulation at 9. Variant located in exon 70 (downstream of exon 63), plausibly affecting brain dystrophin isoforms including Dp71.
quotes: We experienced a case of DMD associated with severe psychotic symptoms in a 19-year-old Japanese male patient.
At a later date, a genetic test with target gene sequence capture followed by a nextgeneration sequence revealed a frameshift variant (p. Leu 3376fs) of exon 70 in his DMD gene.
He was also diagnosed to have a pervasive developmental disorder at 4 years of age by a psychiatrist...
With the revision of DSM-5 criteria, he was diagnosed to have ASD.

In the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-IV) test, his full-scale intelligent quotient (FSIQ) score was 49, verbal comprehension index score was 55, perceptual reasoning test score was 60, working memory index score was 57, and processing speed index score was 61 on admission.
He had no family history of neuromuscular disorders.
A frameshift variant of exon 70 in the DMD gene was the cause of DMD in the present case.
Few studies have been reported on variants of exon 70 in the DMD gene, but these variants are shown to result in a premature translation termination (25).
It is thus plausible that the frameshift variant of exon 70 in the DMD gene led to the severe neuropsychiatric symptoms in our patient.

phenotypic_evidence.age_at_diagnosis: 4 years (pervasive developmental disorder); ASD per DSM-5 (age not specified)
phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: ASD diagnosis per DSM-5; Shyness with strangers; Irritability
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: WISC-IV at admission: FSIQ 49; VCI 55; PRI 60; WMI 57; PSI 61.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: WISC-IV administered on admission during hospitalization; indicates intellectual disability.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy; cognitive impairment; psychotic symptoms (irritability, insomnia, hallucinations, delusions, panic attacks); heart failure (treated with carvedilol and captopril); nocturnal respiratory failure requiring NIPPV; loss of ambulation at 9 years.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Mild cerebral atrophy on MRI.

variant.sequencing_method: Target gene sequence capture followed by next-generation sequencing
variant.variant_description: Frameshift variant in exon 70 (p.Leu3376fs) identified by target capture and next-generation sequencing; exon 70 variants reported to cause premature termination; plausibly contributed to severe neuropsychiatric symptoms.
variant.impact: Premature translation termination; downstream of exon 63 potentially affecting brain dystrophin isoforms including Dp71.
variant.segregation_data: No family history of neuromuscular disorders; inheritance not stated.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (unknown) | Initial score: 1.0 (range: 0-2.0) | Phenotype adjustment (low confidence): -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.5

title: Case Report: Clinical delineation of CACNA1D mutation: New cases and literature review
author: Alzahrani A, et al.

cases.description: We report the case of a 9-year-old female patient, diagnosed with ASD, severe ID, hyperactivity, and aggressive impulsive behaviors. WES revealed a heterozygous previously identified and functionally characterized missense likely pathogenic variant in the CACNA1D gene NM_001128840.3:c.2015C > T (p.Ser672Leu). In the development clinic, she was diagnosed with ASD and severe intellectual disability at the age of 6 years based on DSM-5 criteria.
cases.family_history: Variant present in father (ID, psychiatric illness, late-life seizures) and affected sister (severe ID, psychiatric disorder); absent in mother.
cases.notes: Subject of this case report; labeled as case 12 in the paper’s discussion and tables.
quotes: We report the case of a 9-year-old female patient, diagnosed with ASD, severe ID, hyperactivity, and aggressive impulsive behaviors.
In the development clinic, she was diagnosed with ASD and severe intellectual disability at the age of 6 years based on DSM-5 criteria.
WES revealed a heterozygous previously identified and functionally characterized missense likely pathogenic variant in the CACNA1D gene NM_001128840.3:c.2015C > T (p.Ser672Leu).
This variant was also found in her father and in her affected sister in heterozygous status but was absent in her healthy mother.

The assessment revealed deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction, and in developing and maintaining relationships. The assessment also revealed that she had repetitive speech and motor movements, usually with her hands.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communicative behaviors for social interaction, and in developing and maintaining relationships; repetitive speech and motor movements.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Severe intellectual disability.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Gross motor within normal limits (sat at 7 months, walked at 14 months); fine motor delayed; cognitive and language significantly delayed.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: severe intellectual disability; hyperactivity; aggressive impulsive behaviors; sleep disturbance; attention-deficit hyperactivity–like features

variant.sequencing_method_details: WES performed; heterozygous missense variant identified.
variant.variant_description: Previously identified and functionally characterized missense variant S672L in CACNA1D; associated with autosomal dominant primary aldosteronism, seizures, and neurological abnormalities.
variant.impact: Likely pathogenic; previously identified gain-of-function mutation associated with neurodevelopmental disorders.
variant.segregation_data: Heterozygous in proband, father, and affected sister; absent in mother; segregated with disease phenotype within the family.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (inherited) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Final quantized score: 0.1
